node.text:
How do we build resiliency in our children? Three take aways from this live with @drbeckyathome:
1️⃣Model resiliency 
2️⃣Name and value those “perfect” feelings our kids have
3️⃣Talk about our own failures

node.text:
HOW DO WE HELP KIDS LISTEN?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This has to be one of the most asked questions whenever I do a Q&A: how do I get my kids to listen better? How do I help them be better listeners?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The listening dilemma is one where you are definitely not alone ❤️ “In one ear, out the other” never made quite as much sense until I became a parent 😂
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Today, I’m sharing five tips that I use with my family (and back when I was a teacher) to help kids listen better and reduce that parent / caregiver frustration that comes along with it 🤪
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Check out my 5 TIPS FOR HELPING KIDS LISTEN video 👆🏻 Just a few changes can make a huge difference.

node.text: ⏰OUR WAKE UP ROUTINE⏰ This is NOT an ad for tiny kid clocks 😂 although maybe I could have a side hustle as a product model? 🤷🏻‍♀️ I think I'll stick to my activities day job 😂 I have been SLAMMED (I say this lovingly) with questions lately about kids waking up in the morning, helping kids stay in beds/rooms, and ending the ‪5 am‬ "It's too early to wake up" shuffle 😱 I talk about this in my DAILY ROUTINE post (link in profile @busytoddler) but I wanted to give even more explanation 😊 My kids have these "OK TO WAKE" clocks - Mirari brand from Amazon (this company doesn't even have an IG so believe me when I say they do not know who I am) 😉 In this video, I explain the difference between the two clocks and how we use them with our kids. 👍🏻The clocks turn BRIGHT GREEN (with or without a sound) at whatever time we set them for in the AM 👊🏻 With one of our kids, this is his "it's now OK to leave your room" clock and it turns green ‪at 7:30 am‬ ➡️ For our other kids, this is their “it's OK TO WAKE, it's no longer ‪4 am‬" clocks - and it turns green ‪at 6:30 am‬ signalling to them that they are now free to play quietly in their rooms 😍 As I say in the video and the blog post (link in profile @busytoddler), our kids have safe toys in their rooms, anchored furniture, and a totally kid-approved area to play 🙌🏻 We trained them all to stay in their rooms until either we come to get them or the green light goes on ‪at 7:30 am‬ 💜 We trained them using firm, clear, and consistent boundaries - making this a big priority in our morning parenting - and for the first little bit after the crib to bed transition, we did have toddler locks on their doors for safety (I don't need a 22 month old wandering my house alone ‪at midnight‬) ❤️Obviously, we have video monitors so we can see them, and as always, do what is best / right for your family, practice safe habits, and use your judgment 🎉 In the video, I answer the big question of "don't they wake up hungry?" and in the blog post, you can find information on what I do after potty training (hint: tiny toddler toilet...) 🙌🏻 I hope our routine can help you find and develop the best wake up routine for your family 😘

node.text:
WOW - It's been almost a week since I was on GOOD MORNING AMERICA (@goodmorningamerica) and the feeling is still surreal...like I'm watching some other Mom talk about rice bins on national TV. 
I have so much to be thankful for this year - I can't even begin to list it all out. This moment, being on GMA, it really drove home just how incredible this journey has been for me. You see, my last trip to NYC (before this one) was back in 2012 with my husband, Chuck. It was a much needed getaway at a time when things were really heavy in our lives. Even though we were away on vacation, we had to pause during our trip to handle real life: we sat in a park by the Brookyln Bridge and filled out the paperwork for our 5th and final round of IVF. 
Before that, I had always thought parenthood was just this right we had and I'd never considered what it would be like to have to fight so hard for something that seemed so natural. I was so naive. That day, in New York, we didn't know if parenting was in the cards for us or what more it would take to get us there, but we were pushing forward fighting for something we believed we were destined for. Fast forward a few months and our miracle Sam was born. The final round worked and we'd made it to "parenthood". How poetic to then be back in New York, seven years later, and brought there as a sort-of "parenting expert". Me? This Mom who almost wasn't. I have so much to be thankful for and so many people to thank (I can start with the 657k of you...). Life doesn't always take the path we expect, and I am living proof of that. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for joining me on my parenting journey and for all the magic that's come with it. Happy Thanksgiving, Friends. 
With love and gratitude, Susie

node.title: Busy Toddler on Good Morning America

node.text: 🌟TRAVEL KIT🌟 aka the restaurant kit, the waiting room kit, the car ride kit, the saving my sanity since 2016 kit 🎉🎉🎉 Do you have a kit like this that's your go-to? 🙌🏻 Here's mine that I always have stocked and ready - it's a grab and go type thing - and it’s perfect for holiday events as we enter that season 🦃🎄There's a whole lot of method to the madness of what I have stored tightly into this little kit 👍🏻 The first time I made this, I had a 3 year old, a 19 month old, was having a c-section in two weeks and needed to keep my kids entertained at a company dinner for Chuck 😳 No pressure 😂 So I whipped this up before we left and our so-called “restaurant kit” has lived in my car ever since for moments when we need a little back up 💃🏻 I put all my years of Tetris & Nintendo-ing into packing this thing TIGHT 🤣. It all started with this small wipes container (like Cottonelle, Charmin,  or Scott's brand) - the container is the backbone of this operation because 1️⃣ the container can open and shut easy 2️⃣ The slit on top is perfect for shoving things through 3️⃣ It's jusssst the right size ✨ I have it full of post-it notes, dot stickers, tiny animals, match box cars, playing cards, crayons, and a partridge in a pear tree 😂Ok maybe not the last one😂 But seriously, this kit is EVERYTHING for us 🌟 the thing is: I have three kids and don't have three cell phones so a kit like this is crucial for when we go out places 🎉 I want them to learn to be a part of the action, conversation, the waiting, etc and this helps facilitate that for us - gives us a little more to do as we pass the time ⏰ What's in your "travel kit"? 🤔What's a must for your family when you go out? 🤔 Let’s pack the comments full of ideas so we can all make some amazing kits to help us during this week of car rides, dinners, and travel 🙌🏻🙌🏻🙌🏻 #busytoddleractivities

node.text:
SENSORY BINS 101 - Alright class! It's time for Busy Toddler School - jk but how fun would that be?! Let's talk all things sensory bins today - aka my most favorite activity for kids. Sensory bins are the great equalizers of play - from 12 months old to 12 years old... kids love sensory bins.

But there's a lot of questions around them: how do you make one? What do kids learn from them? And (most important) how do we keep kids from making GIANT messes with the supplies? 
I made a little video for IGTV to answer all those bin questions. Nothing holds my kids' attention quite like a sensory bin... and I want to share that magic with you all.

Cheers to happy, playing kids! XOXO - Susie

#busytoddleractivities #sensorybins #sensoryplay #earlychildhood #letthemplay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Stop comparing kids to each other. BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
Preschools and elementary schools have largely started again and with it comes the season of comparison.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We suddenly see our kids in this mix of children we didn't know yesterday and the urge to compare where they are against others grows.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Please don't fall into this education trap.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
See your child. See their skills, their potential, their loves, their growth, their needs, their strengths, and their path. You don't need to worry how they measure up to your best friend's child or the neighborhood kid who now sits next to them.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Resist. Resist. Resist.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It is hard, I know. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The next time you hear about another child, and it brings up those feelings of compare that burn deep inside us: take a breath. Acknowledge how great that is *for them,* then shift to all the great things you know about your child. They're just as amazing.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I know this is an "easier said than done" post, but as the school year starts, the season of compare rears its head so quickly. This is the time to block out the noise. This is the time to laser focus on your child, their development, their growth, and their needs. No need to compare it to others.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
**please note: If you have concerns about your child's developmental milestones in the early years of life, please speak with their doctor (rather than the lady on the Internet).

node.text:
Anyone else learning about apples right now in a certain preschool program? WINK WINK 😉🍎

This was a favorite of 3.5 year old Kate - my meticulous worker who loves details and line-ups. Dot stickers have always been her activity supply of choice 🔴🔵⚪️

SUPPLIES USED ➡️
Melissa and Doug white butcher paper
Painter's tape (it's wall safe)
Dot stickers (@avery brand - .75 inches)
Everything from a little online boutique called Amazon 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
SKILLS PRACTICED ➡️
This is great for fine motor work, pincer grasp, hand-eye coordination, matching, sorting, and concentration. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
These kinds of activities have always worked for Kate - note that my other two are not in these images. This kind of activity isn't their jam and THAT'S OK. Just like food, every child has a different taste in activities. What one loves, another might hate... nothing wrong with that ♥️♥️♥️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
LINK IN PROFILE to that certain preschool program.

node.text:
✨Kids can learn to play independently✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
THIS IS THE SECOND POST IN MY PLAY SERIES​

I know what it's like to have the kid who will not sit and play. To be so frustrated when you see other children playing so well alone, but can't figure out where to get this child started.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Over time, I developed this skill in my child. It took time. It took firm and clear expectations. It took a lot of exposure to opportunities for free play. Kids can't learn a new skill unless they get exposure to that skill over and over.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Imagine if we put away the bicycle after the first try 🤦🏻‍♀️ We help them get back on. We help them learn that skill.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We can do the same with play.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Some FAQs about independent play:
✨This "unstructured free play" without an adult can begin at birth. Kids are never too young to self-entertain. When you watch a baby staring at the rings on their playmat, you are watching that baby self-entertain. That turns into independent play. 
✨Toddlers and older can learn to grow this play skills. It's unbelievably important. There's no too old or too young to work on play skills. 
✨Independent play is a fancy code phrase for "any play without an adult" - that can be alone, with siblings, or other peers. 
✨Play without adults is extremely important (we will unpack this more in our next play series post). The short answer: when adults play with kids (though well-meaning and full of love), we change the nature of play and some of the benefits of play are lost. This is why it's important kids learn to play without us.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
IF MY PHRASING IN THIS POST ABOUT FOOD EXPOSURES HAS YOU THINKING ➡️ I'm not an expert there. But I've learned a lot from Jennifer at @kids.eat.in.color and she is an expert. She has great posts about just that and helped me learn that verbiage.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
➡️COMMENTS: Can you help another parent who is teaching these play skills and give them encouragement? 
Working on this with your child right now? Let's talk about it! Ask questions. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Play is a skill. Remember that. It can be grown.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Have a child who struggles with independent play? All is not lost. Let's teach them how to build this skill. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Play is a skill Some kids seem to be born nature self-entertainers. Some kids aren't so much. We can build this skill over time, little by little. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Think of play like a food exposure Kids can't learn to like a new food until they've been exposed to it lots of times: A bite here, a taste there, and plenty of exposure. Play is the same way. Kids can't learn a new way to play (independently) unless they get lots of exposure to it. BUSY 4TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Try this play game plan Have a few specific times each day where the expectation is that the child plays while you do other things. Use firm and consistent boundaries and language around this time: "I'm not available right now.' "I'll be able to join you when I'm done with the dishes." Manage your xpectations aim for a few minutes each time they try this new skill. Let them play where they can see you (proximity helps). BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What if they still won't play without an adult? Remember: it's just like food exposures. They won't always take bite or try a new food. Ifthey would rather sit and watch you fold laundry and vacuum, that's their choice. Stay firm in your expectation. am not available right now." Keep exposing them to this new type of play and expectation. It will grow. Little by little. BUSY'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'In the caption: Some FAQs and a few more details In the comments: If ou child has learned to play independently, share some encouragement to others. If your child is learning this new skill, ask questions or let me know how it's going. BUSY 1'.

node.text:
I want to remember that they did this all 👏🏻summer 👏🏻long.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Further proof that my kids come up with better activity ideas than the lady on the Internet.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Enjoy their turtle races 🐢

node.text:
Repeat after me: Kids don’t need fancy to have fun ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Some of my least fancy and least pinterest worthy activities from over the years stand heads & tails above the rest. It’s my forever reminder that how beautiful, or complicated, or photogenic an activity is… that’s not what determines if it’s fun 🎉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
PAINT THE CARS: I let the kids (here 3 and 5) paint metal & plastic cars with washable paint. I looked like such a hero for this unexpected moment of fun - but I knew it would rinse right off in the soapy water.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
To help out future Susie, I did this in a storage container (my beloved 28 qt bin from Target) and added some white construction paper to help with clean up. Sometimes past Susie is the worst. Sometimes, she does stuff like this and TOTALLY REDEEMS HERSELF 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The mosh mash of cars, the small squirts of paint, the beauty of my back patio 🤣🤣🤣 Friends: It doesn’t need to be gorgeous to be perfect and engaging and jump start play and all sorts of other great things.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It doesn’t need to be fancy to be fun.

node.text:
THE FIRST INSTALLMENT IN MY SERIES ON PLAY 🎉🎉

Let's talk about play. We hear it over and over again, "Play is the work of childhood" (Jean Piaget) but how do we get children to that point of play? Sometimes, it's easy (I have a child like that). They just play. Sometimes, it's not so easy (I have a child like that, too) 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
IN THIS SERIES, WE WILL TALK ABOUT ➡️ Kids who always ask for you to play/won't play without you, when to start independent play, what does it mean to play "independently," and what makes an activity play or not play.

TODAY ➡️ a few tips to get you started with building a culture of play in your home. It can be done. We can help our kids be successful with play, whether they are an only child or one of many.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Remember, play is a skill ✨ Just like you wouldn't expect to walk outside tomorrow and run a marathon, we can't expect kids to magically sit and play for hours if that isn't a skill they've been learning.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We build this skill bit by bit. Minute by minute and in small chunks.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Start with these 5 tips ➡️
1️⃣Set a predictable schedule for the day that includes play times (I use these times to do some of my work).
2️⃣Hear your child playing? DO NOT INTERUPT. It's like entering a conversation mid-way or cutting into a train of thought. Chat with them later if you're curious.
3️⃣Let them have their space without hovering or feeling like they're being watched. You can still supervise but give room.
4️⃣Check that they can be successful with their toys and are able to find what they need to play. This might mean doing a toy purge and putting away some unused or not-ready-for items.
5️⃣Show them how much you value play. It's easy for play to come off as a chore instead of the beautiful, rich, and deep learning experience we know it is. Be honest with your kids about play and let them know how important it is for their growth and development.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
IN THE COMMENTS ➡️ Let me know how play is going at your house, if you are comfortable sharing. This will also help with formulating this play series and tailoring it to what is needed most ♥️♥️♥️

Supervise from a (safe) distance 3 MAKE PLAY DOABLE: Leave out toys and supplies they can use without adult help VALUE PLAY: Make sure kids know you value their play work 5 TODDLER'.

May be an image of text that says '1 HAVE A PLAY ROUTINE Instead of play being a random occurrence or only when you need a break, set up specific times each day as play times, just like you may do for soccer practice or homework. This helps kids get into a play routine and know the expectation. 4TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2 AVOID INTERRUPTING If you see your child playing or self- entertaining, don't break their concentration by asking questions. Give them space to work. Touch base later if you want to find out more about their play. SYTODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says '3 GIVE THEM SPACE Play is hard work, and kids need breathing room. It really bugs me when someone hovers and reads what I'm writing as type it... it's the same for kids and play. Supervise from a safe distance. BUSYTODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'MAKE PLAY DOABLE Kids need to be able to find the right tools for their play and to use those tools without adult assistance: Spend some time auditing toys. Donate unused or outgrown items. Recycle broken toys or toys with missing parts. Put away (for now) toys that your child can only use with assistance. ATODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 VALUE PLAY It's easy to accidentally make play sound like a chore or dismissive. "Just go play!" Instead, show your child how much you value their play and the important learning they do when playing. Talk about how play is their job. Instill in them a deep respect for the importance of play and model that with how you frame and talk about play at home. Don't let play be an afterthought. BUSYTER'.
Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 23, 2021. May be an image of child, body of water and text that says 'TRY A COLOR BATH It's the best'.

node.text:
Need a real hero today? I feel that 🤪
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Whenever time is ticking backwards or I'm stuck in that purgatory between nap wake up and dinner, I often reach for a bath. My mom's party line with kids has always been "just add water" and this has always felt right at our house 💦
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Color baths are a riot and a definite 2 for 1 activity ➡️first, decide the color theme and wonder the house together collecting plastic/bath safe items for in that one color. Trust me, this is an activity in and of itself ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Fill the tub like normal, add in all your findings, and let your child be fully immersed in their colorful bath experience with different toys than they normally have in the tub (it's all magical) ✨✨✨

WHAT ABOUT THE FOOD COLORING:
➡️ Food coloring is water soluble. A few drops are MASSIVELY diluted in this tub (aka doesn’t stain), but if this makes you nervous don't do it
➡️ OR use bath tabs or colorful drops (lots of different brands sell these) to color the water
➡️Remember, I'm just some lady on the Internet
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Color bath FTW - color vocabulary, exploring shades/hues, full body learning. I mean, it's a win win win of an activity. Plus it'll help you make it to nap time and beyond... ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Toddlerhood is magic. That person you've been dying to get to know suddenly awakens. Are there challenges? Of course, but there are challenges with all stages in childhood. Toddlerhood is when it all begins to unfold, and so much of who they are comes to life. It feels a little bit like magic to watch. -Susie Allison BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
Someone asked me recently if I prefer the newborn or toddler stage. This was my answer ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Don’t get me wrong, I love the freshness of a baby and all those snuggles… but (for me) toddlers are where the fun starts ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Of course, there are hard days. Trying days. Exhausting days. Days when you wonder how these moments will play out into something you hear older parents longing for…
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But the magic really is there ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The conversations you start to have, the way they reciprocate, and the deep feelings and thoughts you learn that they have…
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The magic is there ✨

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 18, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and text that says 'ko Ko NEED A QUICK WIN? Giant Name Art FOREVER.'.

node.text:
There's something in a name...🎨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Need a quick win to carry you through to nap time or evening time or past the purgatory that exists between naps and dinner? Try some name art with the kids. It's fun and easy and kids love seeing their name this GIANT.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
You can paint this outside or inside: I went outside here with kraft paper taped to our fence (this giant roll is from Amazon and has been with me since 2015. I'm not joking.). I've also done it on cardboard because (shocker) I tend to have some left over boxes in my garage...😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Any way you set this up: it's fantastic. Here, Matt and Kate (then 2 and 4) went to town outside with their names. Names are typically the first word kids learn to recognize and often contain the first letters they memorize too. There's importance in their names in early years learning ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I squirted some washable tempera paint into a muffin tin - my standard paint holding device (sophisticated level is off the charts here). I left this out for the kids all afternoon to bounce and back and forth too - I usually do that with activities. Rarely do they get finished in one sitting. These become an option for the day instead, and that works really well around here. I also put a little wet washcloth out for them to wipe their hands - now that's a real hero here 🤯
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Some FAQ:
Be mindful of your fence with paint - how washable the paint will be depends on your fence, the kids paint, the paint on the fence, and the sun. The lady on the Internet requests that you put this activity in the best spot for your home and family. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Paint I love: @discountschoolsupply and @lakeshorelearning 
The Giant Brushes: All-nylon set from @lakeshorelearning
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Name art is a forever win for us - I sure hope it will be for you, too ♥️

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We need to stop telling children to "be careful." There are better ways to help kids stay safe. BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
The ol’ “be careful” reflex… 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
As uncomfortable as it is for us to watch and consider, children need to develop risk management in early childhood… and they usually develop this right around the time we are shouting “be careful!!” across the playground 🤦🏻‍♀️😬
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Of course, we want our kids to be safe.
Obviously, we don’t want any injuries.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But the next time you get the parental urge to shout “be careful!!” consider this:
Is it actually dangerous (definitely intervene!) or does it just make you nervous?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The often vague “be careful” doesn’t tell our kids anything about what they should look out for or how to be safer, and it undermines their own sense of confidence and good judgment. We want kids to learn these skills ➡️ so instead of “be careful,” we can support their safety, decision making, and problem solving skills by trusting them and offering support.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
“Do you have a plan to get down?”
“Have you noticed how high that log is?”
“Let me know if I can support you in any way.”
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We still can offer help and guidance, but in a much less vague and much more supportive way. It’s a win-win for everyone.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The end goal is to raise kids who are confident, know their limits, and can judge risks, dangers, and rewards. We want them to learn these skills. 

So put “be careful” on the shelf for awhile - and grab for more supportive, specific, and helpful phrases instead ♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We need to stop telling children to "be careful." There are better ways to help kids stay safe. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'During childhood, children need to form a critical skill called risk management. They need to learn how to keep their body safe, to identify pitfalls, and to build self-confidence. They often do this when they are participating in behaviors that make us want to say, "Be careful!!" BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"Be careful!" isn't as helpful as it sounds. When we shout, "Be careful," we can accidentally: Break their concentration Give a generic warning without specifics .Undermine their own judgment Create fear where they might not have any There are better ways to help. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Pause. Before you intervene, look around. Are they in serious danger? Is injury likely? Definitely intervene. you can, let them work things out in their own way. Try this instead But BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Try phrases like: How does your body feel right now? Do you notice that (difficult part)? Have you made a plan to get down? Would you like any help in making a plan? Let me know how can support you. The goal is to assist their decision-making and support their problem solving. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Let's ditch "Be careful." Risk management is a big part of early childhood. Part of our kids learning to trust themselves is knowing how much we trust them, too. BUSY TODDLER 1'.

node.text:
Think Professor Snape would approve? 🧪
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Potion making aka GIANT OPEN ENDED SCIENCE is a staple around here and has yet to get old ✨ I mean, talk about childhood: anyone else do this when you were a kid 🙋🏻‍♀️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Here’s some FAQ/411:
⚗️ We used shaving cream, dish soap (washing up liquid), baking soda (bi-carb), and vinegar - I dyed the vinegar with a little food coloring for give it that something extra ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⚗️ THIS IS OPEN ENDED SCIENCE: there’s no goal. Just experimenting. I give them random droppers, pipettes, syringes, scoops, and all the space to mix abs create
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⚗️ AGES??? We’ve been doing this since age 3 when my kids passed the “you aren’t going to try and eat this, right?” assessment 😉 Use good judgment and think about YOUR child not others.

HOW TO CLEAN UP 💦
Don’t dump this in the grass 🙅🏻‍♀️Carry the bin to the bath tub or sink and rinse out there. TRUST ME 🤣🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ 
Kids need and love space to test and experiment - I know I did! And at least here, I can kind of control the mess… which is more than I can say for my science potions in childhood (sorry Mom) 😉

node.text:
Some days, parenting is easy.
Some days, parenting is not so much.
Some days, I feel like I could go on for always.
Some days, I feel like I might break.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Some days, I remember to ask for help.
Some days, I remember to cut myself slack.
Some days, I remember that I'm human, and all the emotions that come with being human are ok to have even when you're a parent.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I wish I was a super hero. I wish I had super powers.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But I don't.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I'm just a parent, trying my hardest. Some days, I get it right. Some days, I'm ready for a do-over.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Whatever some day you are in today, remember that you are loved, you are important, and you are a good parent.
